fr
end M

e
squyre. her m
tyes
Ambas[sa]dor to

na
ll of thunited Provinces [.]

20 Maij
1595
M
r
Guilpen to M
r
Bodley. From
e Hagh.

page.lettertext:
fol.173r
S
r
. I cannot forbare wrytinge
e last occasion
being offred and yet fearinge as yet nothinge from youe wee
are of opinion that youe are retorned or on
e way hither-
ward
, howbeyt me thinkes
e buisines youe went over w
th
will requyre furdere deliberation
e more for that at yo
r
being there youe myght easely
ceave
e humors and reso-
lution of these men w
ch
I since fynd rather [formed] them
appearant to alter and doothinke verily yf hir
M
tie
should
siste and urge them to the performaunce of that
by youe propownded, they would accordinge to their fascion
alledge
e treatie and Law, and thereby remyane, lea-
vinge
e successe to
e tyme, submittinge them selves, their
State, and all unto hir M
tyes
pleasure, w
ch
they would sygni-
fie by Ambassage or otherwise unto hir highnes. and
thus much in c
o
ference I have understood by som of them:
to discourse theruppon is needlesse fo
[.]
t yo
r
being here
wee reasoned often and debated all circumstances, besyd
I know
youe can looke throwly into
e matter and leave all to
yo
r
w
o
ted discretion / That
e French Warres grow so coalde
doth much trouble them here besyd
e feare, that
e
K:
of S
p
will yelde to a treasure yf he cannot be brought
unto peace w
ch
e
Pope
laboureth hard, and they that
e sayd
K: wilbe doing in
Ireland
& try what he can worke by
Schotland
los
more over that all
e forces w
ch
were
imployed against
Fraunce
wilbe retorned uppon them here,
the grand m
re
de Castille
t Was in burgonigne & cleared
e coast being c
o
into
luxemborgh
already w
th
7 regim
e
ts
of foote & above 2000 horse, yt as thought he wil first reco-
vere in hande / The
States
troupes
t
were w
th
the [said]
duke are cominge home w
th
owt sendinge for o
r
lycence
the foote take their way toward
diepe
to imbarke for
Zelande,
e horse under
e conducte of Co. [p
r
se] passe a long
by
Strausborgh
followinge
e way
S
r
Francis Vere
cam home
by There men seeme disc
o
tented at yt but
e
D.of Buillon
complaynes not greatly, hoping as yt seemes that they wil
in place thereof let him have monie to intertayne certain
fol.173v
nomb
r
of men to make warres w
th
in these quarters / Th'e-
nimie c
o
tinueth his troupes about
Hulst,
his Ex
cie
wil
hasten to
e feelde whyle he hath tyme being written to
S
r
Edward Norreys
for 3 companies, of men & unto
Flusshinge
for 200 /
Count William
is looked for howerly, they of
freesland
have pacifyed their pryvate questions by provision & [.]
c
o
tributions wilbe graunted & their deputyes sent hither w
th
e consents havinge promysed to spare as many men
as possibly they can, to wyne w
th
his Ex
cie
in feelde.
Zeland hath also accorded to c
o
tribute but how much & w
th
what conditions unknowen Vosberghen is looked for w
th
yt
every day, but men wil there more be sent thence th'e-
nimie abydinge on their frontyres. And from
Oostend
th'alarum is looked for, for hulst is w
th
in 4 or 5 dayes
march of yt & that is not w
th
owt daunger, They of
[Hulde] are willinge to submit them selves to
e deputies
but since for thendinge of
e question w
th
the [Earle] but
he differres his resolution until
e retorne of his
Chauncellor hence whoe is thought by this tyme to be
there w
th
him Al thing
els continue in one state / I
wryte not p
nt
ly to my
L: of Essex
for want of good matter
yt may please youe to excuse me & supply
e default
yf youe fynd any thinge in that l
re
worthy his hono
rs
knowledge.
And so w
th
my humble c
o
mendations
I cease & co
m
it youe to th'allmightie Haughe
this 20
th
May
1595
.
Yo
rs
most assuryd & ready to use George Gilpin
